reviewText:
DLC Quest is an amusing game that rightly pokes fun at the gaming industry while at the same time being a genuinely fun platformer.

The game is divided into two parts.  First part is easy and won't really challenge too much, except maybe finding all the hidden items.  The second part has a moderate challenge that adds wall-jumping (which Player must earn by getting the DLC), spikes and a hilarious ending.  It's great to play a game that makes you laugh most of the way through.  Also, for 100% achievement hunters, this game's list of achievements is short and reasonable.

Perhaps not worth full price since the playing time is about 3 hours, but recommended whenever on sale.

A satirical and polemic indie about the continuously increasing downloadable contents after the sale of any game (contents that, as a matter of fact, should already be included in the game itself).

CAUTION: This game is only actually worth it when it goes on sale because it is a short and easy game, but it still serves as fairly decent satire.

There really is not much I can say about the gameplay, replayability or graphics because the game doesn't need to look amazing considering it's puny length and you would already know what to expect from the gameplay. You cannot die, there's close to no physics and unlike the Stanley Parable; when you replay this game, you will get all the same things. However, this game does give an important message about DLC overkill in games. In most games, you will see pre-order bonuses, retailer exclusives, overpriced and stupid DLCs which don't really enhance the game so much as to justify the purchase of DLCs, they seem to serve as novelties nowadays.

This is what makes this game important. Remember the days around the PS2 era where if you bought a game, you got the whole game and not just parts of it which will be filled in with DLC. That made games more exciting and more worth paying for. That all changed with the dawn of expansion packs for the big MMOs and Horse Armour (I'm looking at you, Oblivion!) but it isn't entirely for the worst from what I have seen. The DLCs for Saints Row: The Third have added many hours to the game and are of decent quality rather than being lousy 20 minute long stories which I thought was cool.

The only real issue I have with the game is the fact that I, and many others already know that a lot of DLC is pointless on the PC unless a game doesn't have mod support and on PC, mod support is always expected and always demanded for it to constitute a real PC game" which is fair enough knowing that mods are changing the face of the games industry

Sure, as someone who is involved in games a lot I recognized the reference, but it felt like it was relying on the puncline alone to be the joke.

The concept of finding all of the coins is fine for buying the next item to unlock the next area but, but margins of what is available and what is not means you're searching the entire level of any single missing coins. This causes tons of worthless backtracking looking for hidden sides of walls trying to get that next amount of coins. The snow area was the greatest offender in this regard. You're playing it for the jokes and humor, but you have to get past all the annoying stuff to get to it.

Sure, for the price on or off sale it's good value for the time, but even for maybe an hour or so of solid gameplay it's incredibly boring and full of filler. You're playing it for the references. Which aren't worth it. If you want a good experience, play the first chapter and uninstall it.

You want animation?  There's a DLC for that.  Jumping, weapons, etc... including a true ending, there's a DLC for that. What is happening to the gaming industry? We live in an age of almost circular mistrust and exploitation. With piracy and second hand sales apparently ever increasing and a CONTINUAL drain on the potential earnings of game studios, it's time for them to hit back. And they do this with DOWNLOADABLE content.

DOWNLOADABLE content is the scourge of the consumer, a desperate grab for more money from the creators. We know you bought your game, but pay more! Pay more to see the ending, to see the plots, to improve your power... Pay more to complete your experience!

Okay, that might be slightly unbalanced (and not representative of my actual views, that's for another time), but it was only an introduction. It is hardly going to be news to anyone that some of the practices creeping in to gaming are unpopular, or at best divisive. There are some thoughts that, with the birth of microtransactions and freemium set-ups, we are heading toward some sort of dystopian future for games.

That's where DLC Quest comes in! An indie developed 2D platformer which pretty much bases itself in this vision of the future of gaming, where anything you could possibly want in a game comes...as an extra!

Of course, this doesn't mean that the game becomes extortionately expensive, as this is done with tongue planted firmly within the cheek. It serves to ridicule not only the poor practices that are heading this slippery slope, but also other parts of the general gaming world.

DLC Quest offers two separate, but linked, campaigns – DLC Quest and Live Freemium or Die, which are both provided in the package. Fortunately, the developers obviously resisted the urge to forge a bond with the ironic and hypocritical by making Live Freemium or Die into paid downloadable content.

So what's the context behind the parody? Well, in DLC Quest, the player takes control of Player, a sprite-come-hero that is dragged into the the perils of the village, aided in his various quests by the magnanimous shopkeeper offering all sorts of goodies that are necessary for defeating the bad guy and saving the princess and all of the other gaming clichés you can think of. It must be said that DLC Quest is very short and to the point, with some (but not a lot) of exploration to be done before even 100% completion.

Live Freemium or Die is a “direct sequel” of sorts to DLC Quest, and provides a much more fleshed out experience than that of the former. Continuing the rather contrived storyline to this point of DLC Quest, Live Freemium or Die CONTINUES following Player as he investigates a recent string of related deaths in the village, providing a much larger scale of map for exploration and a slightly more directed story than the first part of the duology.

Gameplay-wise, the DLC duo doesn't really do anything to innovate, nor does it do anything particularly wrong. The game plays as a fairly simple 2D platformer, with each game providing a slightly different platforming mechanic to get around with. It must also be noted that Live Freemium or Die adds a little more of the challenge that DLC Quest was pretty much devoid of. That being said, it's hardly Super Meat Boy and won't provide too much of a headache to anyone. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, as it allows many people to enjoy the concept and humour within, but don't come in expecting to be tested.

So if DLC Quest isn't going to win awards for its gameplay, what about the graphics and sounds? Well, once you've unlocked the audio and visual packs, it can be seen that it is a fairly basic affair. The 8-bit visual style pays good homage to the early days of gaming history, whilst the fairly catchy (albeit short, much like the game) chiptune background music also adds to the aesthetic. These provide a great contrast to the issues of modern and future gaming models that the game attempts to address.

So, if you're wanting a AAA blockbuster that's going to provide you with hours of content and the complexities that come with it, then you are looking in the wrong place. If you're wanting a technical masterpiece or keyboard smashing difficulty, then your experience is not here. If, however, you are looking for a short and simple distraction, at only a fraction of the PRICE of a map pack, with plenty of satirical amusement (As such, it could be described as a much more concise version of what Duke Nukem Forever tried to be), then look no further than DLC Quest – and be happy that the industry haven't quite plunged to the depths that the game attests to!

reviewText:
DLC Quest is a satirical 2D platformer that uses a retro aesthetic to poke fun at modern conventions. You start out only being able to move right. You need to unlock and purchase your way through the game via downloadable content. Don't worry, you use in-game coins to purchase the packs. You need to buy things as basic as sound, animation, and free movement as well as new abilities and cosmetic changes. I'd go into more detail, but explaining the joke would ruin the experience for you. Just know there are some very clever bit of DLC and dialogue that do a good job exaggerating the ridiculous nature of many greedy modern games. The basic plot is to save the princess in the first episode, and to save the town in the second. Most of the achievements are simple, requiring you to simply go through the quest. You can collect all the coins, find and purchase all the DLC packs, and beat the game. There are a few more difficult ones, such as the speedrunning achievements, if you're looking for replay and challenge. I like the music, the art, and the humor. It's a fun little game, but it does have a few problems.

One problem with this game is that it's short. It has a lot of clever things to experience and a decent sized world, especially with the two combined campaigns, but it's still only going to take, at most, a few hours to beat. Also, while the humor hit me well, it may not be for everyone. That, and the fact that after you go through the game and get all the jokes, you're left with just the gameplay experience. This is a bit of a problem because, while it is a good experience as a whole, if the humor gets old then you're left with a short and very easy game. It coasts on the satire, perhaps to a fault. I'd like to see a larger game with this style because the controls, art, and music were all good... but this isn't going to be one you want to replay tons of times unless you're a speed runner. Also, I would've liked more music themes in the game, but the ones that are there are very catchy so I can give that a pass.

Overall, DLC Quest a pretty fun little game that makes fun of ridiculous practices in modern games. If you like classic games, satire, and simple fun then you'll probably enjoy this little experience. I feel it has enough here to be worth the 3 dollar asking price, but if you're on the fence about it, just know that it does seem to go on sale now and then for less. It you want have a little fun with a retro style game that pokes some fun at newer ones, this is for you. Here's hoping we get more games with this nice kind of control and level design in the future. DLC Quest get a 6/10 for being a rather shallow game that makes up for its shortcomings in very clever design humor.

This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend DLC Quest then skip to Results and read from there.

Going Loud Studious creates the perfect satire that really displays how the game industry has changed over the years. DLC Quest offers fun RPG that continually makes you laugh by showing you what is wrong with gaming companies.

Story:
The adventure begins as Player arises within the middle of 2D world. Only able to more right he must find currency that represents real money to buy DLC that unlocks all the basics the game didn’t come with. The princess has been kidnapped and it is up to Player to go and save her from a bad guy, who is like a wizard.

Campaign:
There is no difficulty for this game, in fact there is essentially no combat, and you can’t die. Yet you will continually fight on to collect as many coins as possible. You will meet NPCs that provide you with little to no information, and will continually joke about their purpose. As you progress through the game you will unlock DLC that is required to complete the game, and even have the option to buy DLC that just jazzes it up. The campaign isn’t very long, but it keeps you gripped and there are many little secrets that make you want to keep playing.

Gameplay:
This game gives you a weapon, and the ability to move and jump. You will essentially be running around collecting coins the entire game. There will essentially be no combat, and no reason you should die. In fact the game is a huge waste of time, but it’s hilarious and you will play it anyway. The game is simple and the mechanics are basic, but what makes this game unique is that every little aspect must be purchased with the in game currency. Don’t worry you won’t actually spend any real money as you will find the required currency to purchase the upgrades throughout the levels.

Live Freemium or Die Hard:
Funnily a game called DLC quest actually has no DLC. The second campaign is free and it includes all new levels and even the ability to die. There are traps and even some fights which pose all new challenges to the story. The game offers all new puzzles, abilities, jokes, and DLC that make for a riot. It’s definitely worth checking out, even if it’s not DLC.

Results:
This game is reasonably priced at about $2.99; realistically you will probably play this game for 2-hours so it’s about $1.50 an hour if you want to look at it like that. The campaign is witty and gives a new look to how the gaming industry has changed over the years. DLC Quest sheds a light on how most games today offer DLC that should be included with the initial product. It includes funny jokes, interesting level design, and a simple story that makes you want to actually beet the game. If you like simple platformers and enjoy finding secrets then DLC Quest is the game for you. I would recommend this game, especially if it is on sale.

Pros:
+Simple game mechanics
+Two campaigns
+Lots of DLC (none of which you actually pay money for)
+Funny dialogue and game design
+Amazing story (Where is the princess? What happened to all the villagers?)
+You can totally complete the Grindstone without using the DLC XP Boost. You even get a special message for doing it, but no achievement.

Cons:
-Not as much DLC as promised (I want to give them real money so I can unlock a jetpack horse)
-On Live Freemium or Die Hard if you buy all the DLC you may find yourself stuck at the last section (as there are only enough coins to barely get you through the campaign).

reviewText:
DLC is a fun game, if a little short... or at least it's 'suppose' to be short, but word of warning right now - COLLECT ALL THE COINS YOU SEE! If, like me, you manage to somehow miss 14 coins you could end up running around for an hour trying to find them. This might not make sense right now, so early in a review, but if you play it you'll understand.

What DLC Quest does is capture the current state of AAA Games and makes a great social commentary (that's 'satire' to you and me) game out of it. The concept is simple, you're a player and you're in a gameworld, but everyday 'normal' abilities don't seem to be present... until you visit the DLC STORE!
It's one of the true funny games I've played over the years and really manages to put the humor across nicely.

In terms of gameplay DLC Quest isn't too far removed from your 16-bit platform adventure games, so don't expect anything amazing or groundbreaking in that regard. However, the 'story' really makes this game something worth playing, if only to spot all the references and go 'ooooh yeah, I know that!'.

So if you have an hour or two spare and want a little break from the AAA-Games scene, and have a spare £1/$1 to your name than you could do far worse than buying DLC Quest. It's a game that is self aware and runs with it, providing funny moments along the way. Just collect those coins.

reviewText:
DLC Quest is a satire to the video games industry and it's practices. Especially off course the constant DLC releases. Starting the game you can only move to the right and you have to buy DLCs for everything including jumping, weapons, horse armor (Oblivion anyone?) etc. Keep in mind that you buy those with in game money.
The game includes two campaigns but don't expect them to last too long. Both of them are pretty small but still you can have a good time playing them. There are many fanny moments and playing through the game you will recognize a lot of references to other games.

Being an indie game don't expect great graphics or sound effects. On the other hand the controls are pretty simple which is something that suits the game a lot. DLC Quest is mainly a platformer and you will spend the whole time jumping to platforms  and avoiding traps, but there aren't any enemies at all.

So in conclusion DLC quest is a game that will give you a few hours of fun and laughts and that's it.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed DLC Quest. It's fun to play, has a charming atmosphere, and is quite humorous in poking fun at lots of cliches and tropes of the video game industry. At its core, it's a simple, comedic sidescroller with an ostensibly generic storyline, yet it never hesitates to point out its own the irrational logic, from its cliched characters to the seemingly bizarre aspects that are currently part of today's gaming industry.

The premise behind DLC Quest is that a bad guy captures a princess, so obviously it's your job to stop him and rescue the damsel in distress. Heard this story a million times before? So have the developers at Going Loud Studios, so what they've done is put their own spin on this age-old premise. Your task is to first collect enough coins to buy DLC within the game world itself. A clear commentary on the cash-grubbing nature of the video game industry, these little packs are initially required in order for you to do the most basic actions, such as moving both in directions and being able to pause the game, As you progress, the game gives you some nice aesthetic features as well as weapons/items.

I was surprised at how good the control is. The jumping mechanic feels like the original Super Mario Bros. (where you can control height and momentum in the air), which I appreciate immensely. You move left and right at a reasonable pace, too. The controls are customizable and the graphics are vibrant and appealing. Aesthetically, the game's design gives it an NES feel. The dialogue is often hilarious, with characters acknowledging their ridiculous requests or their arbitrary roles in making you run off and do stuff because...uh, that's how games work. DLC Quest on a whole is very tongue-in-cheek that way. That being said, there were a couple things that I thought could be improved. To progress through the game, you obviously need to get enough coins to purchase certain DLC items, but a couple of times I couldn't figure out where to go, because I thought I had cleared out all the areas. Turns out there are some secret areas you have to look for where the walls are missing their borders, which are easy to miss. There are also some areas that you might not realize you can get to for similar reasons (boulders or bushes obscured by the foreground, etc.). Otherwise, I found the platforming to be relatively easy, simple enough for an old fogey like me to get through.

Overall, I think DLC Quest is a very creative, imaginative, quirky, charming, humorous game well worth its price point. It pokes fun at itself and other gaming cliches, but even though it admits its own faults
date: it still kept me wanting to play. If you're at all into sidescrollers, I'd recommend giving this one a try.

reviewText:
Let’s start with defining what DLC is.

DLC is an abbreviation for DownLoadable Content. If a game comes out and the designers make something new for it and they want an extra buck, they sell that bit of coding as DLC rather than making it an update for the game. Games such as Playstation All-Stars Battle Royale or The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim are known for having plenty of DLC, if you’re willing to spend another 5 bucks to buy whatever it provides. DLC can range from new characters, items, enemies, maps, quests, and practically anything else. DLC is completely optional to buy, you can still play the game without it, however the developers would prefer that you DO buy it.

You do not need DLC to finish the game

Well, there’s one game that’s an exception.

DLC Quest Review

DLC Quest is a quirky, funny, no-holds-barred 8-bit platformer that revolves around buying in-game DLC. It has the normal platforming elements such as collecting anti-gravitational coins floating in midair, jumping on unsuspended grass platforms that are oddly stable, and killing helpless innocent sheep because it’s a video game and there’s no real life consequences.

The DLC part of the game is where the humor begins. When you start the game, you can only walk to the right. No jumping, no crouching, heck, there’s not even any animation to your character. You shortly come across a salesperson who decides to break down the fourth wall and sell you DLC with the coins that you collect in the game. You then buy animations, basic movement, wall jumping, guns, zombies, elaborate moving backgrounds, the works.

DLC Quest likes to poke fun at other video games. For example, if you walk to a certain spot in the game, you will have a random encounter with a familiar character with blond, spiky hair and an extremely oversized sword. He refuses to let you pass, until you end up buying some DLC that serves practically no purpose to you or the super soldier that stands in your way, but he wanted it for reasons even he doesn’t know about. you give him the DLC, and you move on.

The game is quirky and funny, but is rather short. Though it has two parts to it, DLC Quest is only about two hours long. The only sidequests in the game are hidden DLC packs you can unlock that serve little purpose to gameplay. Once I completed the game, I found little reason to revisit it again.

The Verdict

DLC Quest is fun while it lasts, but the only problem is that it doesn’t last long. It has a great sense of humor and is a nice addition to anyone’s platformer library.

DLC Quest: 7.5/10

reviewText:
There are some games that build themselves around a gimmick, and if you don't enjoy that gimmick for very long you quickly part ways with the game. There's another game (not this one) that has goofy control that was funny at first but that I wasn't really willing to cope with to actually finish that game past its second stage.

In this case, this game does a lot of jokes about the bad DLC practices that happen a ton in some modern gaming where, instead of true bonus content you can buy if you want more, they nickel and dime you for things you need to enjoy the game in the first place. There was a point in the game where I saw the reviews that said the makers drew the game out too long and the joke gets spent up and trying to complete everything becomes tedium instead, and I could see that they had felt the game had outstayed its welcome on its gimmicks.

I could understand that perspective but not personally share it. While I won't try to get every single achievement (I've got all but two of them, and seeing what those two are I don't think I want to get myself out of sorts getting them)... I really enjoyed the jokes this game pulled and the bits of commentary it did. It turned its DLC jokes into actual gameplay mechanics in some cases, and each thing it had you 'buy' or do felt like a little unique bit of commentary under the overall DLC subject or in some cases actually ended up being things you would buy with in-game money anyway like better weaponry. I personally got a kick out of the guy who said he had nothing to say now but would be important later - I've seen plenty of RPGs that did just that, and were less upfront about it.

Anyway, I guess what I'm saying is I personally enjoyed this game and the different DLC jokes it pulled instead of feeling like it outlived its fun like some other reviewers feel. At the very least, it's inexpensive enough that you can give it a go and walk away when you personally feel sated without breaking the bank, even if your experience doesn't mirror mine.

reviewText:
Let’s start with defining what DLC is.

DLC is an abbreviation for DownLoadable Content. If a game comes out and the designers make something new for it and they want an extra buck, they sell that bit of coding as DLC rather than making it an update for the game. Games such as Playstation All-Stars Battle Royale or The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim are known for having plenty of DLC, if you’re willing to spend another 5 bucks to buy whatever it provides. DLC can range from new characters, items, enemies, maps, quests, and practically anything else. DLC is completely optional to buy, you can still play the game without it, however the developers would prefer that you DO buy it.

You do not need DLC to finish the game

Well, there’s one game that’s an exception.

DLC Quest Review

DLC Quest is a quirky, funny, no-holds-barred 8-bit platformer that revolves around buying in-game DLC. It has the normal platforming elements such as collecting anti-gravitational coins floating in midair, jumping on unsuspended grass platforms that are oddly stable, and killing helpless innocent sheep because it’s a video game and there’s no real life consequences.

The DLC part of the game is where the humor begins. When you start the game, you can only walk to the right. No jumping, no crouching, heck, there’s not even any animation to your character. You shortly come across a salesperson who decides to break down the fourth wall and sell you DLC with the coins that you collect in the game. You then buy animations, basic movement, wall jumping, guns, zombies, elaborate moving backgrounds, the works.

DLC Quest likes to poke fun at other video games. For example, if you walk to a certain spot in the game, you will have a random encounter with a familiar character with blond, spiky hair and an extremely oversized sword. He refuses to let you pass, until you end up buying some DLC that serves practically no purpose to you or the super soldier that stands in your way, but he wanted it for reasons even he doesn’t know about. you give him the DLC, and you move on.

The game is quirky and funny, but is rather short. Though it has two parts to it, DLC Quest is only about two hours long. The only sidequests in the game are hidden DLC packs you can unlock that serve little purpose to gameplay. Once I completed the game, I found little reason to revisit it again.

The Verdict

DLC Quest is fun while it lasts, but the only problem is that it doesn’t last long. It has a great sense of humor and is a nice addition to anyone’s platformer library.

DLC Quest: 7.5/10

reviewText:
A nice little satire/parody about videogame editors/distrubutors's choice to put DLCs for about anything, from stupid or useless features to mandatory stuffs that should have been in the original product from the start and which purpose, clearly, is to milk more money from the player.

In this typical 8bit platformer game, DLCs are actually the backbone of the gameplay. You have to purchase DLCs for almost everything that makes the game! You want musics or sounds in it? buy the DLC... You want animations? buy the DLC... You want to jump? buy the DLC... You want to be able to walk left-side? buy the DLC... You want a village to explore? buy the DLC... You will have to buy most of them if you want to progress. There's a lot of humor and the game is obviously not affraid to break the 4th wall, along with lots of reference from other videogames.

If you're not affraid of playing an old-timed platformer, this one actually do feels like playing an old Nintendo Game. It is well made in that optic, with chiptune musics and all. The controls are very responsives and anyone used classic platformers such as Mario (or more recently SuperMeatBoy) won't have trouble with this one. It is very short, though. But also very cheap.

reviewText:
This game costs less than most DLC and is smarter than anything you've played recently.

Do I want to sit here and press 'X' 1,000 times to complete the task, or buy the DLC that means I only have to press 'X' 5 times?

A satire, a brilliant, blatant ♥♥♥♥ take of current practices within the video gaming industry.

More of a political statement on the gaming industry than an actual game itself.
It's well executed and repeatedly makes it's point.

Most of the enjoyment comes from the games not so subtle commentary on EA, microtransactions, day 1 DLC, Map packs and other 'trends' totally killing and retarding our beloved gaming industry currently.

DLC Quest takes shots at a lot of popular franchises inclding FF7, COD, TF2 and of course Pay to Win games. References ranging from random nods to downright brutal observations, that will, if you're smart enough, leave you questioning your position on some of your favorite games and develpoers.

The game plays like Super Mario. Essentially a simple side scrolling platformer. The Princess is taken by the bad guy at the start of the game and by purchasing DLC you can unlock content that allows you to finsih the game.

It's not a question of if you have the skill to complete the game. It's a question of if you are smart enough to understand what it's trying to highlight.

Most of you won't like it. There isn't a Season Pass available.

reviewText:
This was recommended to me by a good friend with a similar taste in games as me, this was a game I had heard of but never bothered looking into, I hadn’t watched the trailer or anything. I took a gander and it looked amusing so I thought I would give it a go and I was actually pleasantly surprised with what I found.
DLC quest is very simplistic. It hasn’t got a massively complex mind-twisting plot line, it isn’t overly hard gameplay wise, and it actually isn’t even that long of a game… but one thing for me was certain, despite all those things, it was very satisfying. It plays on the mechanics and features of classic adventure games well, and in a tasteful way. There’s so many references and fun things to find along the way that makes you chuckle to yourself and say “I see what they did there…” and I really think that the humour in this game is what makes it great even though it’s so simplistic.
The game also has this OCD “collect it all” thing going on as well, which I can never get enough of, especially if it’s somewhat easy to do. I spent around 2 hours on this game and left it 100% done, all “awardments”, all coins, everything. And it’s a great feeling being able to do that. It didn’t take long, sure. But I think it was just the right length, and didn't feel like it was all for nothing.

All in all, this game is great. And better yet, CHEAP. It has nice music, a wonderful humour to it, a somewhat interesting and random storyline, good controls and everything on that technical side and a great feel to it atmospheric wise.

Buy it!

reviewText: An amusing riff on publishers' attempt to over-monetize their titles contrary to the actual artistry of the title. DLC Quest is a one-joke game, but it's a funny joke and it fortunately knows when to let it go. It succeeds where other similar satires fail (I'm looking at you, 2004 Bard's Tale!) because rather than drag on and on trying to milk that single joke into a full-length game, DLC Quest is - wisely - a very short experience As in, less than an hour long to get to the end. As such, it is barely worth it's price, especially since the gameplay is that of an uninspired platformer. Still, it's rare that a game gets me to crack an honest smile so even if it does seem a bit overpriced, I'll forgive it because it actually was funny.

DLC Quest
Genre:Platformer

Description:The game's emphasis is on upgrading, using satire to parodize modern games that require DLC and microtransactions to enjoy fully by making simple mechanics cost in-game coins. Other than that, it is a simple platformer, with some occasional combat that consists of mashing a button to kill an enemy. Overall it was worth the few dollars I spent on it: a simple platformer with a twist. The one problem I had is that it's extremely short; I was lucky to even get a few hours in it, as most playthroughs seem to take anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour. It's short but sweet.

You're just not going to get Upton Sinclair's The Jungle in the 21st century, certainly not some type of work that makes people reevaluate what they're doing, what they're giving, and what they're getting in return. reviewText: DLC Quest shares a premise with earlier indie game Evoland (take an abstract concept of commentary on the video game industry and turn it into a game itself) and unfortunately suffers the same fatal flaw: abstract concepts of commentary on the video game industry make terrible game premises. DLC Quest, however, manages to be even WORSE in this regard, because its core premise has no progression even built in; it's literally one overextended joke about how much AAA publishers contempt for the consumer comes out in their handling of Downloadable Content for published titles, and in fact it's not even that sophisticated. Much as the game itself is only £2 (65p at time of writing) the fact is that without charging actual money for DLC the game loses any real investment a player could have in the satire it's peddling because there's an absence of the actual tangible effect of the relatable concept; but it can't do that because doing so would undermine its stated political standpoint. The idea was doomed from the start and in terms of realisation of that foretold failure DLC Quest, like Evoland before it, does not disappoint.

reviewText:
Played this game for 30minutes and I saw nothing that interests me about this game whatsoever. I have no intentions of playing this anymore but I just want people to know that if you really want to enjoy this game you have to sink more than 30minutes of mindlessly going to things pressing the action button to buy more dlc" while listening to mindnumbingly poor 8bit tracks that repeat over and over again (I presume that you'll be given an option to "purchase better music" further on in the game) and constantly backtrack trying to collect coinss to purchase more dlc.

The concept of this game is as you should know by the game trailer to buy dlc. The game developers did exactly that and I would give them a 10/10 for that.
The score for 'enjoyability' 0/10 and it's cause this game does nothing unique or special from other 2D adventure platformers besides having the player purchase a ludicrious amount of ♥♥♥♥ for the game.
The score for the story is 1/10. The story is a generic save the princess scenario and is nothing unique as well as the writing for the npcs feel lazily written.
By the way you can't skip 'cutscenes' which are basically powerpoint slide transitions so I had a blast with those as well.

Unless you are willing to sink more than an hour of what I've stated above
date:
I would recommend that you save your money and buy a coffee or something else useful to you and bask in the glory that you didn't waste time like I did.
Feel free to downvote this and buy the game and see for yourself what the game's about. I might be wrong about all of this but I don't want to waste anymore time playing a game that I feel is a waste of time and money.
